subsubsection.title: Vocabulary
subsubsection.p:
Look up the definitions of new terms in the Glossary.
Function of two variables
Joint variation

li.p: The notation z = f (x, y) indicates that z is a function of two variables, x and y.
We can use a table with rows and columns to display the output values for a function of two variables.
We say that varies jointlyvaries jointly with x and y if z = kxy,~~~ k\ne 0
We say that varies directly with x and inversely with y if z = k\dfrac{x}{y},~~~ k\ne 0, ~~ y\ne 0
We can represent a function of two variables graphically by showing a set of graphs for several fixed values of one of the variables.
Explain the difference between the symbols f (ab) and f (a, b).
Why is it true that f (ab) = f (ba), but not usually true that f (a, b) = f (b, a)?
If z varies jointly with x and y, and we hold one of the input variables constant, what will the graph look like?
What is wrong with the statement "z varies jointly with x and y, so z = f (xy)?
